content: The reason Thunderbird may stop working with a VPN is the very same reason a VPN is used for, i.e. to hide your real IP address. If you appear to the mail servers as having an IP address they don't allow connections from, for example, that would prevent Thunderbird from being able to use those servers. Have you checked whether the same happens with a different mail client?
creator: DavidGG

content: Some VPNs have 'split tunnelling' options to allow specified apps to bypass the VPN, but if not, mail apps are blocked for the reasons stated above.

content:
Start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode and see whether the problems happen there as well. The following article explains how to do that and why it can be useful to help identify the cause of a problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

If the problem persists, what's your Operating System? If Windows, start Windows in Safe Mode with Networking mode:

https://support.microsoft.com/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode

If this is a Windows related issue (e.g. some antivirus you have installed causing it) I won't be able to help you with that other than tell you to try disabling the antivirus and see whether that makes some of the problems go away, but post back with the results in case someone else can.

content: This may be a problem with updating prefs.js file. Any change made is immediately effective, but if thunderbird closes without updating prefs.js, then changes are lost.It might be that the file is in read-only state, or an antivirus program is interfering. A way to check is to look in windows file explorer at the profile to see the date that prefs.js was last updated. and sometimes there may be multiple copies of prefs.js, such as prefs-1.js, prefs-2.js, etc. If you see that, I suggest deleting all except the one with highest number and rename that to prefs.js. Do this while thunderbird is not running. Even if that works, the bigger question is what is interfering with updates. What I wrote here may not be the problem, but it definitely sounds like it.
creator: davidsk

content: Holà, Offenbar benutzt du Linux. POP oder IMAP? Einfach nur Postfächer (Accounts oder Konten) übertragen ist nicht die einfachste Methode zur Migration der Thunderbird-Daten von einem PC auf einen neuen PC. In der Regel ist es am einfachsten, den Ordner Thunderbird bzw .thunderbird (unter Linux) vom alten PC auf den neuen zu übertragen und bei beendetem Thunderbird im entsprechenden Verzeichnis einzufügen. Eine andere Möglichkeit wäre, das zuletzt benutzte Profil (bzw. den Profilordner) vom alten PC zu kopieren, auf dem neuen PC im Verzeichnis .thunderbird einzufügen und dann mittels des Profil-Managers neu einzubinden. Wenn dein Screenshot die neue Installation anzeigt, dann fällt auf, dass sie vier verschiedene Profile enthält. Es ist völlig unklar, welches das aktuelle Profil ist. Falls du nur die Profilordner vom alten auf den neuen PC übertragen hast, dann kann das nicht funktionieren, denn TB befragt beim Start die profiles.ini Datei um zu wissen, welches Profil zu öffnen ist. Wenn du also die profiles.ini nicht vom alten PC kopiert und in .thunderbird eingefügt hast, klappt das nicht.
creator: Mapenzi

content: If the intent is to move message folders to Local Storage, that may be insufficient for thunderbird to identify the profile. That is, if you successfully place message folders in the Mail\Local Folders folder of a new profile, thunderbird looks to see if there is an account. If not, I believe it creates a new profile. So, my suggestion is to add an account prior to copying those folders in. This is not in disagreement with @Mapenzi, as that individual provides excellent advice; the issue may be no understanding exactly what your full intent is.

content: The installed dictionaries are listed under Settings/Composition/Spelling, Language:. There's also a 'Download More Dictionaries' link. Or, install from this page. Language packs only change the text of the interface - dictionaries are for spelling.
creator: sfhowes

content:
"How can I see which are the largest files in my inbox?"

The Size column can be displayed in Table View to show each message's size (right-click any column button to enable other columns). Right-click a folder, Properties, to see 'Size on disk'.

Messages with attachments are usually the largest, and attachments can be detached (saved then deleted) or deleted.
creator: sfhowes

content:
If you use 'Threads' and a thread is in a 'collapsed' state then clicking on that collapsed threads means open all threads therein in separate tabs - this has always been the means of opening up everything because you are clicking on an entire thread and not an individual mail in thread.

If you 'expand' the thread first then you can click on any email in that thread to display in either Mesasge Pane or in separate tab. It will only open the selected email.

The alternative to see all comments in a thread is to use a right click and select 'Open' > 'Open Message in conversion' and that opens one tab with all other threads listed both incoming and outgoing.

content:
Here goes: - first, click account settings and then synchronization&storage and click 'advanced' button to verify that the folders can be downloaded - then, click File>offline/download to ensure that all headers and messages of all folders are eligible for downloaded - now, install the addon, importexporttools NG. - now, highlight each folder separately, rightclick and select importexport option to download mbox - once finished, copy to USB

- if you need to read them later, you can revert the process as this: - highlight Local Folders - rightclick and select importexport option to import mbox. repeat for each folder

What you have is an IMAP account and can be verified by clicking account settings and checking top pane for the account which will state POP or IMAP. An IMAP account resides on the server, not the PC. That is why there are extra steps.

content:
Gabriela Rączka said
How can I unhook my email address from Thunderbird without deleting it normally? I have an account connected to GMAIL and I want to detach it only from Thunderbird

Account Settings, select the account, Account Actions (bottom of left pane), Remove account. This will remove it from TB, but not affect it on any other device or app. The Default account cannot be removed, so set another account as default before removing the gmail account.

Do you understand what Troubleshoot Mode does and why does it help to diagnose problems? https://support.mozilla.org/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

content: This clearly points to a networking issue. I mentioned the possibility that it could be a VPN, but if you check that article, you'll see there are other things to look at (e.g. firewall settings). One thing you may do to further narrow the issue is connect the computer to the router with an Ethernet cable, to isolate whether the problem is in the WiFi or some other router misconfiguration.
creator: DavidGG

content: Hi, Just tried the direct connection to the router and it did not work. Then immediately tried to send an email wirelessy which also failed. We do not have VPN. Regarding firewall settings, what should we be looking for? We are not technically minded...
creator: tracey16

content:
Right now I don't know how to remotely, using this forum, troubleshoot this on your computer with the OS you're running and the router you have. Basically you should look for things that could be blocking Thunderbird from being able to communicate with the SMTP server.

In principle, this could be caused by some piece of software running on your computer, such as an antivirus, or some other kind of security software, or the firewall that comes with the OS you're running… Even without knowing how to fix the problem, you would be able to at least figure whether that piece of software is causing the problem by creating an exception for Thunderbird if there is a way to do that, or temporarily disabling it if there isn't, seeing whether that makes the problem go away, then enabling it again.

The fact that you seem to be able to send using someone else's Internet access, however, would seem to indicate the problem is the router you're using (which has its own firewall, btw, independent of the OS firewall), not something you have installed on your computer, but right now I don't know how to troubleshoot that for you. Maybe someone else does…
creator: DavidGG

content:
If you are on Windows, using the most recent version of Thunderbird 128.6.x or 128.7.x, ...

  • Start Windows in safe mode with networking enabled - https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode
  • Still In Windows safe mode, start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Does problem change?

If it did not improve, please create a profile using https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiling-thunderbird-performance
creator: wsmwk
